instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PP1V05_S5: What is PP1V05_S5? PP1V05_S5 is a 1.05v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. On 2008-2009 15” and 17” Macbook boards, this often gets stuck at 0.3v due to a bad C7771 capacitor. .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS: What is PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS? Power rail on 820-2850 logic board for the GPU framebuffer, that is often underpowered and intermittent because of a dying C9560 capacitor that must be replaced on this model to avoid black screen & kernel panics..
definitions.PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R: What is PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R? Power rail on 820-2850 logic board for the GPU framebuffer, that is often underpowered and intermittent because of a dying C9560 capacitor that must be replaced on this model to avoid black screen & kernel panics..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
got in a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with a good green light and orange with battery plugged in.  it powers on to 1/4 fan spin. was liquid damaged. i took the power rails down, it only gave me voltage when the fan is spinning.
it appear <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S3</SIGNAL>  and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> are missing.  

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> -3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> - .75v

<SIGNAL>PP18V5_S3</SIGNAL> - 0v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> -1.05v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0GPU</SIGNAL> -1.05v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> -0v

<SIGNAL>PP1V0_FW_FWPHY</SIGNAL> -1.4v

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_ENET</SIGNAL> -1.19v

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0</SIGNAL> -1.18v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL> -1.5v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL> -1.49v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> -1.34v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R</SIGNAL> -1.34v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_GPUIFPX</SIGNAL> - 1.8v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> -1.8v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_ENET</SIGNAL> -3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_FW_FWPHY</SIGNAL> -3.31v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> -3.31v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU</SIGNAL> -3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> -3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> -3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> -3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.38v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> -5v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> -5v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> -5v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> -12.58v

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> -18.88v

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> -.90v

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> -1v

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX</SIGNAL> -.87v

<SIGNAL>PPVP_FW</SIGNAL> -13v

<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL> -.75v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: You answered the question already, or do you think missing <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> is normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
well the only thing i am confused about is where <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> is getting connected to power if <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> is not attached, also <CAPACITOR>C7740</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7741</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R1825</RESISTOR> etc  are also not attached those are the only places on the board <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> shows up.  and they are not suppose to be there i checked with other boards, but the schematics do not say no stuff.   

should <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S3</SIGNAL>  be present also?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Ugh, so you didn't even check if the parts are even on the board. Of course there is no <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> if <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> is not there. Look at the note with <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> why they thought it might be needed.
18V5 is for trackpad, who cares?

Where was liquid damage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: okay i understand.  right that is what i was thinking.  the liquid shows bad signs around the graphics and cpu,  also like wise on the back side center top area everywhere around the <CHIP>ISL6263</CHIP>, i ran it through the UC because it was under the big chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Could be corrosion under CPU/GPU. Check all traces and resistors around <CHIP>ISL6263</CHIP>.
